Posts.Content: Hi Have you had an onctoype dx test done.  This may help to determine whether you will need chemo or radiation.

Posts.Content: My bone density test was a T-score of -1.6 Ostiopenic of the lumbar spine.  which state I have increased fracture risk. How detrimental will taking Arimidex be ??
Posts.Title: Osteopenic!!Will Arimidex make it worse!!!!!

Posts.Content: On Sep 19, 2015 11:48 PM supercw wrote: i had mets to lungs and just cleared it all in 4 months. this is so long ago you posted i would love to hear how it worked out with your friend. (and any others in this board). i did a combination of natural remedies and chemo - i read the book Radical Remission and followed each of their 9 principles. that's it. four months.  not too much pain barely any complications lot of hard work but it's very do-able once you've found the solid will to live. bless, cw  Hi cw May I ask what kind of chemo did you take? How long did you have to take it?   Did you do intravenous Vit C? while taking the chemo Can you give me a brief idea of the natural remedies Thanks Rosieo

Posts.Title: Stage 4 Metastasis to the Lung

Posts.Content: On Apr 03, 2011 12:34 AM Tooshort1 wrote: First surgical biospy showed DCIS without clear margins.   Due to small amount of breast tissue and implants, decided to have mastecomy (also bilateral to stop worry about occurrence in other  breast).   Surgeon stated he looked at nodes and saw only one that appeared to be swollen so he removed that one not taking any others.  Biospy results came back talk about total shock- I had 75% tumor DCIS but the remaining amount was infiltrating carcinoma.  The report stated not enough nodes were taken to biospy I guess to determine if spread.   Ok, I go to my surgeon for appt and he states the amount of infiltrating cancer boiled down to 1/8 of an inch and that he was not worried about it spreading.   I mentioned the node and he stated he did not take a sentinel node at surgery and did not see reason to do so now.  He also stated the chemo and radiation onocologist said I didn't need either treatment based on that small amount of infiltrating cancer.   I am all confused about this situation.  First of all - I had mammograms and ultrasounds since age 30- I am now age 55.   I had dense tissue with cysts is the main reason for both.   I have never missed one year having both done outside of maybe being a month later than the previous year.   I have asked and they seemed to not have an answer- how did I end up with invasive cancer having my screenings every year.  Has anyone ever had a same or similar problem like this.   Now my current exisiting concerns are - even though I had mastecomy - since the cancer was invasive - should I not have some type of treatment such as radiation or chemo.    Also I cannot understand why this doctor didn't go ahead and remove a sentinel node just to err on the safe side rather than letting go and playing 'God' thinking everything was just ok. Has anyone had a mastecomy with invasive and not had treatment?  What about the node situation? Hi I just had a second mastectomy.  I had a mastectomy 16 years ago with 1 bad lymph node.  I had no chemo, only Tamoxifen for 5 years.  No problems. Now 16 years later I had a 1.4 tumor, no lymph node involvement, clear margins, a clear bone scan, clear chest xray, clear cat scan of liver, and my oncologistwants me to take chemo.  Not what I want to do.  Why should I poison my body when I have no sign of cancer now.?
Posts.Title: confused after surgery- nodes and treatment

Posts.Content: On Jul 24, 2011 8:50 PM Connie64 wrote: Thanks for the replies. I am on medication. 2 anti-depressants but because I have gained so much weight in the past year, they don't work as well. But i am too depressed to stick to a diet. I am a pathetic loser. Things just got worse. My mom is losing her hair. She never did during her first bout of cancer in 1988. But she is now. She's handling it as well as one could expect her to. It will take everything I have in my not to totally break down when I see her these week to take her to get her hair cut short or shaved....... Thanks for listening to me rant. Hi Connie You are not alone with the way you feel about your Mom. For many many years I always had the fear of losing my Mom.  I would think to myself "How am I going to deal with it"  What am I going to do without her".  So I always tried to do the best that I could for her, one of the reasons being that if I did not do all I could I figured for sure I would just have guilt added to my fear when she would be gone.  Well my Mom passed away, it will be 10 years this year.  I think of her everyday and I still have some of her things still in her room. I am telling you this because I would like to help you to know that things will work out for you.  Do whatever you can for your Mom now and know that we all must leave someday, but with God's promise we will see our loved ones again.  Also remember your Mom would never want you to feel bad.  That is how my Mom was.  She always worried about me and I am sure your Mom is the same.  I hope I have been able to make you feel better.  If you need I will be glad to share more with you. God Bless
Posts.Title: thoughts on depression

Posts.Content: Hi can you explain "letrole one pull a day" I too would like to look into hyberbaric chamber. What state do you live in  I am in Pa.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with stage 4 breast mets

Posts.Content: On Jun 03, 2011 10:04 AM imula wrote: I have been diagnosed 4 weeks ago with a 6 cm tumour Invasive Lobular Cancer. Aspiration biopsy in one lymph node was negative, but that may or may not be too indicative. Due to the size of the tumour I will most likely need radiation therapy as well as chemo and hormonal therapy.   I saw the surgeon yesterday and she suggested a unilateral mastectomy. I opted for a bilateral mastectomy. I just could not cope with having one breast!!! I find it easier to have none.   We also talked about reconstruction and she was fairly negative about it. She advised that the chances of success are not that high because of the radiation therapy which may be detrimental to the reconstruction. Also surgery may have to be delayed because plastic surgeons are very busy. Potential complications may also delay chemotherapy. But she said that it is my decision and that it does not matter much if the procedures are delayed by several weeks. I find this hard to believe...   I just don't know what to do. Have you had this dilemma? Have you had reconstruction followed by radiation? Or delayed reconstruction or none at all?   Also I am ER+ and PR+ and I will definitely need hormonal therapy. That really scares me as I heard that there are difficult adverse effects. Have you had ny experience, good or bad, with Tamoxifen or Aromatase Inhibitors? It is still unclear to me after having read a lot on the internet what the benefits of these hormonal drugs are after double mastectomy. Do you know? I would be grateful for any advice/experience, positive or negative. Hi I too have had both breasts removed.  I am ER positive, no lymph node involvement, and clean margins. My oncologist wants me to take Arimidex.  My bone density test shows I have osteopenia and I am very much afraid to take this drug be cause I too have heard terrible things about it and I like you wonder how much of a plus this will be for me to take.  I have the prescription now for a month and have not had it filled yet because of this fear. I mean how much estrogen can I have yet, I am 75 years old. One thing I would advise you to do is to have a oncotype dx test done on your tumor to see if you will need chemo.  It may save you from having to take it. I can tell you I had my first breast surgery 16 years ago.  I took Tamoxifen at that time for 5 years with never a problem. I would like to discuss further with you about the oncotype dx test
Posts.Title: what are the benefits of hormonal therapy after double mastectomy

Posts.Content: On Apr 21, 2011 3:17 PM Tooshort1 wrote: Had surgical biospy in Feb. had 2.7 cm removed (tumor was 2.5).  Path indicated DCIS with unclear margins.   Surgeon order MRI after the biopsy - report indicated 2.5 cm neoplasm remained.  I opted for bilateral mastecomy- prior to surgery asked surgeon what if the remaining area had became invasive - his reponse your report says DCIS.  I asked the question again during our discussion - same answer - your path report indicated DCIS.   On the morning of surgery - I asked about lymph nodes - he had mentioned during our office discussion - that he would look at the nodes and take any suspicious but would likely NOT take any nodes.    On the surgery morning he stated the same thing when I asked him about nodes.   After surgery he told my family - he had taken one node that was swollen- he had no idea what node he took or why it was swollen - I had not been sick.    He did not take the sentinel node - which I understand is pretty much standard procedure.    When my path report came  back from the mastecomy - it indicated there was a 0.3 cm of infiltrating ductal carcinoma.    When I went back for my surgical follow up I asked him about the invasive and he stood there looking like he had no idea what I was talking about.   He took me and I had my daughter and friend come in- into the conference room.  He came in in obviously a bad mood about my question.  He said he wasn't concerned about a 1/8 inch of invasive cancer and radiology was going to say no radiation and chemo guy was going to say no chemo.   He then started mumbling and mentioned he had not taken the sentinel node.   He then started to dismiss me and asked had I decided how 'big' I was  going to go with my implants and that he understood the surgeon who was doing my reconstruction would take me a large as I wanted to go.   Now why the heck would he waste his time asking me who at this point could care less about the size of my new  breasts- I was concerned about the fact infiltrating cancer had become a part of my life.   He scheduled an appt for the next week and pretty much told me if he had known the remaining area had invasive cancer he would have taken the sentinel node - hindsight is 20/20 Doc you were treating undignosed remaining tumor as knowing what it was when in fact you didn't have a clue.   He told me he had met with onocology and they said no chemo, no radiation, no more surgery to remove any more nodes and no hormone suppressant - even though tumor both DCIS and invasive were positive for estrogen and progesterone.   I sat there and about died - I asked the question how did he know there wasn't cancer cells sitting in the sentinel and would end up going somewhere else.  He then jumped in my s for lack of better wording telling me he could order chemo and I could sit for six months and watch my hair fall out  or he could order radiation and I could suffer from lympodemia (spelling not right) and he gave the percentage of women who get this or he could do more surgery and went into the scare the wrath of God out of you with the gross graphic details.    He told me the hormone therpy had lots of bad side effects.    Now based on my information - is it pretty much standard procedure to remove the sentinel node or to at least obtain a better sampling on the nodes WHEN A MASTECOMY IS DONE REGARDLESS OF ORIGINAL DIGNOSIS. HAS ANYONE EVER HAD INVASIVE CANCER EVEN THOUGH VERY SMALL AND NOT HAD SOME TYPE OF TREATMENT IF THIS WAS YOUR SITUATION  WOULD YOU TRUST THE SURGEON AND HIS OPINION/COMMENTS/RECOMMENDATION AND BE ABLE TO LIVE WITH IT OR WOULD YOU GET A SECOND OPINION ADDITIONAL INFORMATION   this surgeon works for a privately owned breast center.    I requested all my hard copy mammogram and ultrasound reports - I had been going to this place for 7 years and having dignostic mammograms and ultrasounds due to dense breast tissue with cysts.   I had been ordered to have both since age 30 I am now age 55.    I obtained hard copy reports for 07, 08, 09 and 10 (the later was when they found the cluster of microcalifications).   It appears in 08 there the ultrasound noted grouped microcalifications in the right breast.   Then in 09  when I went for the screening the ultrasound woman told me there was nothing in my breasts including cysts, etc.  She was short tempered with me and seemed in a hurry.   The day I was there was the first day the breast center had opened at their new location.  I have that report stating no problems.   So apparently in their grand opening first day at new location mode - they over looked what was there and likely in the 'works' the year before.  I have asked them the question - how did I have mammograms and ultrasounds every year and have breast cancer that had became invasive.   They have not answered that  question.  I have ordered both a CD of my last two year mammograms and they are sending me the ultrasound hard copy films. After reading this last section as well, how do you all translate the issues with my situation.  Is it just in my head or is there a problem with the  breast center, the surgeon and his attitude and recommendation for treatment? Any input will be appreciated HI I have just had a mastectomy of the left breast. 16 years ago I had a mastectomy of my right breast.  At that time I had 1 "bad" lymph node, tumor 1.2, and I only did Tamoxifen for 5 years, no problems. Now my tumor is 1.4, clear margins, no "bad" lymph nodes but I guess it is still considered invasive because it is not DCIS. I am still waiting for a oncotype test to tell me if I should have chemo because the oncologist wants me to do chemo. I do not want to do chemo!! If my cancer 16 years ago had 1 bad lymph node and this time I have no bad lymph nodes, why should I need chemo!!! I am already thinking when the test comes back I will refuse the chemo even if it says I should take it.  I feel perfectly fine and am very sacred of the side effects of chemo.
Posts.Title: Surgeon did not take sentinel node

Posts.Content: On Jul 15, 2011 10:28 PM lizzy4e wrote: I am a 25 year hodgkins and now have stage 1 breast cancer and was told i can have IORT to remove tumor.  I have a lot of questions and need some answers can any one help me!   Thanks Liz Hi Lizzy I had Hodgkins around 35 or so years ago.  I got breast cancer 16 years ago. I had a mastectomy (could not get radiation again because of the radiation treatments for the Hodgkins) I then took Tamoxifen for 5 years.  Now after 16 yrs I had breast cancer for the second time.  Again a mastectomy no radiation and the oncologist wants me to take Arimidex.  I also was Stage 1.  But what is IORT? I will be glad to help you with your questions.
Posts.Title: ?Hodgkin's lymphoma survivor and now stage1 breast cancer

Posts.Content: On Jul 27, 2011 9:45 PM Windymoose50 wrote: Hi Lizzy, Have a friend that this happened to, they explained it that the breast cancer occured from the radiation from the lymphoma and she is now cancer free.. Gayle Gayle how long ago did you friend have the breast cancer.  I don;t know if you read my story but I had breast cancer twice 16 years apart.  Did your friend have it twice or just in one breast, did she have to take chemo and is she on aromatase inhibitors.  I appreciate the information Rosieo
Posts.Title: ?Hodgkin's lymphoma survivor and now stage1 breast cancer

Posts.Content: On May 28, 2011 2:00 AM djsandiego wrote: Dx, with Stage 1, grade 3 invasive ductal CA right breast. Had double mastecomy, final path report shows no lymph envolvement, and clean margins around the cancer site. Awaiting Oncotype results to see if need chemo. Onocologist states will need med next five years, after reading about all the side effects wondering if its a good idea, have arhritis in by low back, scleraderma, my joints always ache anyway, can't aford any more time off work, this is where my insurance is from. I'm 4 weeks post op, still confused, worried, and uncomfortable,having reconstruction done also. I'm 54 years young. Any input in should I or shouldn't I take a anti cancer drug. A nurse I am and I can't answer this ?  Help, hanging in there. Hi I too am trying to decide whether or not to take Arimidex as prescribed by my oncologist.  My bone density test shows I have osteopenia in my  spine and could have fractures so I am petrified to take something that I have read so much about in relation to being hard on your bones.  I too had Stage 1, double mastectomy, no lymph envolvement and clean margins. I chose not to have reconstruction.  My oncotype test came in at 1.  I hope you have a good result too.  Let me know what you decide on the meds.
Posts.Title: ? need for to start any meds amridex or toxafin

Posts.Content: On Apr 28, 2011 8:58 PM sharalou wrote: OMG! Just went to oncologist.  Had a biopsy on Monday, and came back as same type as breast cancer. His plans, pet scan (on Monday), see oncol. neck surgeon,and possibly rads. I just finished chemo in December. Anyone else with similar situation?  Would love to hear from you. Going to see another oncologist tomorrow, and possibly one more in AnnArbor Mi.     Hi I can feel the anxiety in your posts.  I too have had breast cancer twice.  Last mastectomy Jan 23rd.  I hope your trip to the oncologist on April 29 th turned out ok. This cancer is defintely a BEAST.  It really takes over your thougthts and daily living. Again I hope all is well with you.
Posts.Title: Lump in Neck-POSITIVE-FROM BREAST CA

Posts.Content: On Jun 06, 2014 3:15 PM soleybyfaith wrote: I'm late in responding. 3 years in fact. But maybe it is still useful. I did prophylactic bilateral mastectomy in 2012 (4 surgeries total: Mastectomy, 2 weeks later reconstruction with implants, 8 months later cellulitis of right breast- implant removal and replacement, and then a year later liografting over the implant to increase tissue and blood flow as the area had thinned out). The BC data is very impressive mmimicking and maybe even exceeding that of the BRCA gene and since I work in oncology it spoke volumes to me. I was most worried about if/when BC occurred, we as hodgkin's survivors would have limited to no options for radiation as treatment (unlike brca). If I had BRCA I might would have waited it out and rolled the dice. But these limited treatment options following radiation worried me. Plus, my husband really wanted me to consider it. Score one on the husband points!  I had hodgkins 21 years ago treated solely with mantle radiation. Long term effects I've experienced: asthma, hypothyroidism, fatigue (cause effect unknown as we all have fatigue!). I didn't want to add BC to that list. My journey is chronicled here if that wouldbe one any help to you. I went in to it rather iniformed. Won't make that mistake again. So now I reallyw ant to advocate for women who choose this path. www.tradinginthetatas.blogspot.com "" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.tradinginthetatas.blogspot.com " target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.tradinginthetatas.blogspot.com Wish you well as you navigate!   Sally sally thanks for your reply.  As much as I read on here I still can't understand a lot of things, for instance, what is the difference between BC and BRCA. My story is Hodgkins probably 30 years ago,(not sure of years, as it was so long ago) but then breast cancer 15 years.  Mastectomy right breast.  Now 3 years ago, breast cancer left breast.  I did not do reconstruction.  Too much of a baby.  Did you have to have chemo?  My worry now is where will the cancer go next. Rosieo
Posts.Title: Radiation-induced breast cancer (long term side effect)

Posts.Title: Radiation-induced breast cancer (long term side effect)

Posts.Content: On Jun 03, 2011 2:57 AM OKnow wrote: Thanks Karie! After I sent the posting I googled the subject and did find a two other women who had radiation for cobalt then BC years later. Only one was told directly by the doctor that the BC was radiation-induced. It's just good to hear from others. Thanks again. Peace. Hi Please read my message to lolite.
Posts.Title: Radiation-induced breast cancer (long term side effect)

Posts.Content: On Jun 06, 2011 11:34 PM iolite wrote: Hi, just to let you know that you are not alone in this matter.  My younger sister was diagnosed at 14 with Hodkins and received cobalt at 14 & 16 yrs. She was caught at a later stage and the drs. said they would not be able to cure it but possibaly put it to "Sleep", well they did and it slept for 24 yrs.  She is now 46yrs. old and fighting breast cancer with oral chemo since the drs do not want to give her more chemo.  She had chemo at the age of 18 for a reacurance of hodgkins, and that put it to sleep for 24 yrs.  It awoke at 42 yrs.  She proceeded to have more chemo, and it was good for a year and then popped up again....another round of chemo again...clear for a year and then the breast cancer was diagnosed a being cause by having had the massive radiation treatments done to her at the age of 14 & 16 yrs old.  They did not want to give more chemo via the port, due to the face that she is now also a cardiac patient due to the chemo.  She had a mastectomy on the one breast and the cancer came back in her scar and there was another lump as well, they decided to do oral chemo as a last ditch effort, it is working, the scar has completely healed and the other lump is almost gone.  She is going to be taking updated radiation after the 6 units of the oral treatments in hopes of kicking the cancer out of her.  Your stories sounded so alike I wanted to let you know you were not alone with this.  If I can answer any questions just let me know.  I too am fighting lobular BC, was diagnosed last June and had only a lumpectomy since I was only a stage 1.  All is good, taking tomaxafin for the next 5 yrs.  Have a very blessed day. Hi Yes you are not alone.  I too had Hodgkins around 40 years ago for which I had cobalt radiation treatments.  Over the years I had many non cancerous breast lumbs removed until finally 16 years ago I was diagnosed with breast cancer and had a mastectomy because as the Dr. told me I was not a candidtate for radiation treatments due to the fact I had the radiation for the Hodgkins.  So I had the mastectomy which showed only 1 lymph node involved.  I did not need chemo and took Tamoxifen for 5 years.  Now lo and behold again I have just been diagnosed with breast cancer again in my other breast.  I again had a mastectomy in February with no lymph node involvement.  No chemo due to the oncotype dx test.  My oncologist wants me to take Arimidex which I don't think I want to do after learning what it can do to your bones. I have read that anyone who has had Hodgkins when they were younger and had radiation is very likely to get breast cancer.!!!I mentioned this to my oncologist and he said yes that is true!!
Posts.Title: Radiation-induced breast cancer (long term side effect)
